body:
@piiswrong I check caffe commit log, negative_slope was introduced in 7.22.2014. this is a long time bug...

although in current version, the negative_slope is always present, but it can also be removed in the future, so add 'hasattr' judgement is more safe. I had updated the pull request

@szha
I install 2 versions of mxnet on different pc:
1, mxnet-cu80==0.10.0.post2 and "d220e192897da763ed8e8a6135f9e8b24cc1a2ce"
2, mxnet-cu80==0.11.0rc3 and "53274b4a2b0d73f3fbdb10cfb5f9ed0c8263fda7"
And both have the problem mention above ...
Do you mind sharing a small chunk of data so that I can run the program and debug?

Research shows that this error is usually due to a bug in the compiler's
optimizer. One such bug was fixed in 2017 version.


On Sun, Sep 3, 2017 at 12:17 AM Chris Olivier <cjolivier01@gmail.com> wrote:

> In my build_test branch I have several iterations. Some built, just
> finding one that's closest to the proper intent that msvc won't choke on.
>
> On Sun, Sep 3, 2017 at 12:14 AM Chris Olivier <cjolivier01@gmail.com>
> wrote:
>
>> On Windows?  Mine passed on the build server AMI. I can get several
>> permutations to pass. I will get it working on Tuesday.
>>
>>
>> On Sat, Sep 2, 2017 at 11:31 PM Haibin Lin <notifications@github.com>
>> wrote:
>>
>>> I was trying to build your branch on Ubuntu DL AMI but make failed with
>>> the same errors that appeared in CI
>>>

@KCHWang It's been a while. Did you happen to find the solution? I'm facing same problem.

This example code doesn't work with Python 3 yet. If you create a new conda environment with python 2.7, the example will run fine. I was able to run the full data.ipynb notebook in this conda environment:

```
conda create --name mxnet-py27 python=2.7
pip install opencv-python requests matplotlib jupyter mxnet future
```

I had a feature map of dim(HWC).
H->Height, W->Width,C->No of channels.

I would like to apply convolution operation on 3-dim feature map to have output like...(hwr2l)
h->height of modified feature map
w->width of modified feature map
r2->no of channels of modified feature map.
l-> no of label map and each label map is of resolution hw*r2.

How to implement this in mxnet?
Kindly provide solution....
break ndarray.md into two parts: NDArray Class and basic operators. Then add random, linalg etc
you can use pooling or convolution with stride to do downsampling
thanks got the solution.... Closing the issue
Also the same problem in OSX EI 10.12.5. Reinstall opencv can't solve it.

yes,replace the json and params to http://data.dmlc.ml/models/imagenet/inception-bn/
Everything is OK~!
Any updates on using Torch functions in mxnet? is it possible?
This seems like a bug - I will look at it tomorrow.

This is ready for merge, conditioned on:

https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow/pull/280
Could you explain?
@piiswrong fix a shape error in warpctc example
@piiswrong tested

It seems that this issue also occurs in branch 0.11.0
The branch with tag 0.11.0.rc3 is fine.

@thirdwing I am now getting the following testing failure.  I don't believe I saw this before; has there been a change in the testing environment?

```
1. Error: UNET (@test_img_seg.R#95) --------------------------------------------
there is no package called 'imager'
1: library(imager) at R-package/tests/testthat/test_img_seg.R:95
2: stop(txt, domain = NA)
```
please update submodule

Have you tested this?
param is used before assignment.

Please verify this on a actual protobuf since it's not covered by test cases

Please add a license header to all your .py files like the other examples and we can merge.

Thanks

I am not sure about changes in the testing environment.

In your case, it seems `libxt-dev` hasn't been installed.
@jesterhazy I see. Thank you for your help!

@piiswrong  I am embarrassed for this mistake. I fixed it on another old repo, then copied the fix code to this branch to make this pr. one line was missed along this way.

I had fixed this error, and tested the converted model, it is ok now.

I'm stumped on how to install `libxt-dev`. Doesn't the testing environment build everything from scratch for every commit, so in particular wouldn't this library get installed?  I have also noticed the following two errors, which I believe at least in part lead to `imager`'s inability to load:

```
libdc1394 error: Failed to initialize libdc1394
```
and
```
xlib-backend.c:34:74: fatal error: X11/Intrinsic.h: No such file or directory
```

@jiarenyf unfortunately I wasn't able to reproduce the problem. I'm using an EC2 p2 host which has K80 GPUs. I was able to run 100 epochs without problem. Also, I'm running from the current head of mxnet.
```
INFO:root:Epoch[100] Time cost=2.508 ...
```
Could it be hardware/driver issue?
It seems that your network is somehow expecting `uint8` for the weight while receiving `float32` type instead. Could you try to cast the data using `data = data.astype('float32')`?
Emm.. i didn't notice it, It works. Thanks for your help! @szha
@freshmanfresh no problem. It seems to be a recurring problem, so I made a PR to update the error message to display the type string instead of type codes in #7730
Ok, I did reproduce it. Will debug it now.
Happening for me as well on Ubuntu 16.04

Ok, I understand why it happens:
reset() function in Python calls BeforeFirst function in C interface, which is supposed to reset the iterator. BeforeFirst function is also used after the epoch ends to reset the iterator. Since the dataset size may be indivisible by the batch size (and it is in the example shown by @chenboheng), by default ImageRecordIter resets itself and takes images from the next epoch to fill the last batch (it is shown in the first output shown in this issue - 2 last images from the last batch are the same as 2 first images of the first batch). Then the "reset" of iterator does not actually reset it - if it was, it would read those 2 images twice. 
In order to improve performance, ImageRecordIter prefetches a few batches of data. It turns out that this dataset is small enough that the iterator prefetches all of it in those 2 seconds when the main thread sleeps, and so it reaches the end of epoch internally. Calling reset in that situation calls BeforeFirst in the same way it would be called after epoch is done, so it does not actually reset the iterator, but prepares it for a new epoch, with dataset being offset by those 2 images that it used to fill the last batch of the "previous epoch". That is why the result is different.  
So basically the bug can only be observed if the dataset is small enough that it fits in internal prefetch queue, the size of dataset is not divisible by the batch size and we give it enough time to internally process the entire dataset.

I guess the possible solution would be to treat the BeforeFirst as the end of epoch and not hard reset only if the end of epoch was actually reached through calls to next. I will look into fixing this. 
Still, the "reset" name kind of suggests it will completely reset the iterator and that is not the case if you reach end of epoch. @piiswrong What do you think about it? Is it acceptable?
Maybe [this](https://github.com/opencv/opencv/issues/9446) build-environment related issue could help.
I have same problem
Besides the examples, can we add some unit test cases?
Could you paste the command you used when installing from pip and the output of that command?

You might have more than one copy of python and your ipython/Jupyer has old mxnet in its site packages and it wasn't upgraded. You can open a notebook, import mxnet, and then print mxnet to find where the old package is. Note down the location, find the pip command in the bin folder at the same level as the site-packages you found from last step, and explicitly use the absolute path of the pip you found for installation and upgrade.
@piiswrong @mli
Honestly I'd rather see the logic for confusion matrix entries in one place instead of 6.
done
You can't use NDArray inside operators
@nswamy
Closing for now. A more general refactor on entity serialization in mxnet may be needed.
Could you also fix it for https://github.com/ashokei/incubator-mxnet/blob/1e03a82dc72fc38f47bbffe010f1c1fe2edb381e/src/kvstore/kvstore_dist.h#L131
@rahul003 @bhavinthaker @reminisce @cjolivier01 @anirudh2290
I wonder if #7747 will help with my problems.
I am afraid we are not using the Travis anymore.

The simplest way to fix your error is to change this line (https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/tests/ci_build/install/ubuntu_install_r.sh#L27) into 

```
apt-get install -y r-base r-base-dev libxml2-dev libssl-dev libxt-dev
```

Just adding `libxt-dev` should fix the testing.

`libxt-dev` should be installed by default and this is a little weird.

Do you mean you want to find the maximum value for each channel? Suppose your feature is packed as an NDArray, with shape of `(12, 800, 1280)` (i.e. `CHW` layout), you can do
```python
mx.nd.max(data, axis=0, exclude=True)
```
This performs maximum search on all axes except 0th axis. Information on this API can be found at https://mxnet.apache.org/api/python/ndarray.html#mxnet.ndarray.max

I want to perform element-wise maximum among all the channels
I/P : N*H*W
O/P : H*W.

Thanks for your reply !I follow your instruction and build the net as this:
from mxnet import gluon
```
class poolLayer(gluon.HybridBlock):
    def __init__(self, numOut,**kwargs):
        super(poolLayer, self).__init__(**kwargs)
        with self.name_scope():
            self.bn1 = gluon.nn.BatchNorm(axis=1, center=True, scale=True)
            self.relu1 = gluon.nn.Activation(activation='relu')
            self.pool1 = gluon.nn.MaxPool2D(pool_size=2)
            
            self.conv1 = gluon.nn.Conv2D(channels=numOut, kernel_size=3, strides=1, padding=1)
            self.bn2 = gluon.nn.BatchNorm(axis=1, center=True, scale=True)
            self.relu2 = gluon.nn.Activation(activation='relu')
            
            self.conv2 = gluon.nn.Conv2D(channels=numOut, kernel_size=3, strides=1, padding=1)
    def hybrid_forward(self, F, x):
        # F is a function space that depends on the type of x
        # If x's type is NDArray, then F will be mxnet.nd
        # If x's type is Symbol, then F will be mxnet.sym
        print('type(x): {}, F: {}'.format(
                type(x).__name__, F.__name__))
        x = self.bn1(x)
        x = self.relu1(x)
        x = self.pool1(x)
        x = self.conv1(x)
        x = self.bn2(x)
        x = self.relu2(x)
        
        x = self.conv2(x)
        x = F.UpSampling(x,scale=2,sample_type = 'nearest')
        
        return x
```

@ArsenLuca , To implement spp, you actually need adaptive pooling, but mxnet does not support it now. Fortunately, there is [PyTorch that support it](http://pytorch.org/docs/master/nn.html#adaptivemaxpool2d). If you can not implement it by yourself in MXNET, consider PyTorch. aha :)

You can use the ROIPooling function used in Faster RCNN
[`mx.symbol.ROIPooling`](https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/api/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.ROIPooling)

As far as I know, mxnet does not support subpixel upsampling layer yet. Still, you can emulate it using a series of transpose and reshape layers. I am currently using the followings, messy but works anyway.

``` python
def subpixel_upsample(data, ch, c, r, name=None):
    '''
    Transform input data shape of (n, ch*r*c, h, w) to (n, ch, h*r, c*w).

    ch: number of channels after upsample
    r: row scale factor
    c: column scale factor
    '''
    if r == 1 and c == 1:
        return data
    X = mx.sym.reshape(data=data, shape=(-3, 0, 0))  # (n*ch*r*c, h, w)
    X = mx.sym.reshape(data=X, shape=(-4, -1, r * c, 0, 0))  # (n*ch, r*c, h, w)
    X = mx.sym.transpose(data=X, axes=(0, 3, 2, 1))  # (n*ch, w, h, r*c)
    X = mx.sym.reshape(data=X, shape=(0, 0, -1, c))  # (n*ch, w, h*r, c)
    X = mx.sym.transpose(data=X, axes=(0, 2, 1, 3))  # (n*ch, h*r, w, c)
    X = mx.sym.reshape(data=X, name=name, shape=(-4, -1, ch, 0, -3))  # (n, ch, h*r, w*c)
    return X
```

@piiswrong  Fixed

The problem is the command executed by Jenkins server is not the same with commands in Jenkinsfile.

For example, the command executed in https://builds.apache.org/blue/organizations/jenkins/incubator-mxnet/detail/master/287/pipeline/280 
```
tests/ci_build/ci_build.sh cpu R CMD INSTALL --library=/workspace/ut-r-cpu/site-library mxnet_current_r.tar.gz
```

However, in our Jenkinsfile (https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/Jenkinsfile#L382):

```
sh "${docker_run} cpu R CMD INSTALL --library=/workspace/ut-r-cpu/site-library R-package"
```

Sorry that I don't know why they are different.
